description: From Middle English gerle, girle, gyrle (“young person of any gender”), perhaps from Old English *gyrele, *gyrle, from Proto-West Germanic *gurilā, from a zero-grade form of *gaurā (“young child”) +‎ *-ilā, ultimately of unknown origin.

entries.meaning: A female child, adolescent, or a young woman.
(sometimes offensive) A woman, especially a young and often attractive woman.
A female servant; a maid. (see usage notes)
examples: Synonyms: char, charlady, charwoman, maid, maiden, maidservant, womanservant

entries.meaning: (card games, slang, uncommon) A queen (the playing card).
(colloquial) A term of endearment. (see usage notes)

examples: There isn't any guy going to steal my girl!
Your girl turned up on our doorstep.

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, obsolete) A roebuck two years old.
(US, slang, uncountable) Cocaine, especially in powder form.

examples: Are there “boy” trees and “girl” trees? Yes. A number of species, among them the yew, holly and date-bearing palm, have their male and female flowers on different trees. The male holly, for instance, must be planted fairly close to the female ...

entries.meaning: (derogatory) A boy or man who is weak or sentimental.

verbs.description: girl (third-person singular simple present girls, present participle girling, simple past and past participle girled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To feminize or girlify; to gender as a girl or as for girls.
(somewhat informal) To staff with or as a girl or girls.
examples: Making our way past a one-girl switchboard temporarily girled by two frantic operators, we found the victorious president, Elliott A. Bowles, barely visible behind a heap of telegrams [...]
